isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 9800 - AIR CONDITIONING BASIC THEORY, SYSTEM DIAGNOSIS AND SERVICE (WITH R-12 REFRIGERANT SYSTEM) - REFRIGERANT SYSTEM SERVICE - FLUSHING THE AIR CONDITIONING SYSTEM

svcsubproc.title: R-12 Charged Air Conditioning Systems
svcsubproc.para: The flushing of refrigerant lines and parts in R-12 charged air conditioning systems is done with R-11 refrigerant. This refrigerant is used because it remains liquid at room temperatures and pressures.

caution.para: Do not use any solvents other than R-11 for flushing refrigerant lines and parts of R-12 charged air conditioning systems. The reaction of other solvents with refrigerant will cause sludge, which will damage some parts and be much more difficult to flush from the system.

svcsubproc.para: Special refrigeration system flushing equipment is available from various air conditioning equipment manufacturers for R-12 charged air conditioning systems. This equipment employs a continuous circulation flushing method to thoroughly and quickly clean a badly contaminated system without removing the major system components.
If this equipment is used, carefully follow the equipment manufacturer's recommended procedures for equipment use and system flushing.
If special equipment is not available, the system may be flushed using the following procedures.

caution.para: R-11, like R-12, is a chloroflurocarbon and is covered under the same regulations. R-11 must be handled with the same cautions and may not be vented to the atmosphere. While R-11 is a liquid at normal room temperatures, it evaporates very quickly; therefore, it must be stored and recovered in sealable containers.

step1.para: Recover the refrigerant from the system.
Remove high and low side hoses from compressor and place covers over valve ports to prevent the entrance of moisture.
Remove expansion valve. Clean out with a small charge of liquid R-11.
Connect length of heater hose to the expansion valve connection of the evaporator.
From service line components, fabricate a short refrigerant line to connect between the evaporator suction line and the manifold gauge set suction valve.
Close the manifold suction valve and discharge valves. (Turn fully clockwise.)
Connect the service hose from the center manifold fitting to the valve on top of the charging cylinder of R-11 refrigerant.
Open the refrigerant supply valve on top of the charging cylinder.
Slowly open the suction gauge valve and allow liquid refrigerant to flow through the evaporator to a sealable container. Allow at least one pound of R-11 to pass through the evaporator.
Close the refrigerant supply valve on top of the charging cylinder.
Remove the fabricated refrigerant line from the evaporator suction line.
Remove the hose from the evaporator inlet and reinstall the expansion valve to the evaporator line only.
Remove and discard the receiver/ dehydrator.
From service hose components, fabricate a short refrigerant line to connect between the condenser inlet (compressor discharge) line and the gauge manifold discharge valve hose.
Connect a piece of heater hose to the condenser outlet line. Insert the other end of the hose into a sealable container.

Make certain that manifold suction and discharge valves on the gauge manifold are closed (turn fully clockwise). Open the refrigerant R-11 charging cylinder valve (still connected to the center manifold on the gauge manifold).

Slowly open discharge valve on gauge manifold to allow the liquid refrigerant to flow through the condenser to a sealable container. Allow at least one pound of refrigerant to flow through the condenser.
Close the refrigerant supply line.
Remove the fabricated refrigerant line from the condenser inlet line. Remove the hose from the outlet line.
Use a small amount of R-11 to flush the line which connects the receiver/ dehydrator to the expansion valve.
Install a new receiver/dehydrator and re-connect the air conditioning system.
Connect the manifold gauge set and charge with one pound of R-12 refrigerant as described in this section. (Do not evacuate the system until after the leak test.)
Leak test all connections with a leak detector. If OK, then proceed with Step 12. If not OK, repair the leak and then go on to Step 12.
Evacuate and charge the system with R-12. Refer to CHARGING THE AIR CONDITIONING SYSTEM (FULL CHARGE).
Allow the system to run for ten minutes and perform oil level checks.
Perform SYSTEM PRESSURE CHECK of the refrigerant system to assure quality cooling performance.

svcsubproc.title: HFC-134A Charged Air Conditioning Systems
svcsubproc.para: At the present time, there is no flushing agent for HFC-134A charged air conditioning systems. R-11 and any other flushing solution that is currently used to flush R-12 charged air conditioning systems CANNOT be used to flush HFC-134A systems. The residue left by these flushing products will destroy the lubrication properties of the oil used in HFC-134A systems.

The only procedure presently available to flush an HFC-134A charged air conditioning system is to pressure flush with HFC-134A refrigerant using a recycling system to capture the HFC-134A flushed through the system.
